metadata.name: CorpNet-Subnet-A-With-Identity
metadata.description: Example corporate environment with multiple subnets (core + HR/Finance) including Windows servers, workstations, and an identity/privilege model

security_profile.blast_radius_hint: Compromise here can alter routing and expose internal services to the internet.
Firewall compromise enables arbitrary access into DMZ, core servers, and HR/Finance subnet.
Compromised VPN GW can grant direct remote access into user and server networks using stolen VPN profiles.
Internet-facing; compromise here is a common entry point and can be used to pivot to app-1 and db-1.
Compromise exposes app-layer credentials that can be re-used against db-1 and other internal services.
Direct compromise equals major data breach; any upstream app or admin path to this host should be treated as high-risk.
Common lateral movement pivot; ransomware on this host impacts many departments at once.
Compromise can be used for internal phishing and data leak of entire mailbox stores.
Tier-0 asset; compromise gives effective control over all domain-joined systems and users.
Primary admin pivot; compromise here often equals effective full-domain compromise.
Common initial foothold; compromise can be used to reach web-1 and internal file shares, then upward.
Compromise can expose finance data and provide credentials to specialized finance applications.
If ALICE's creds are stolen, attacker gains local admin on key servers plus access to engineering data.
Domain Admin; compromise of BOB gives direct administrative control over most Tier-0 and Tier-1 assets.
Credential theft leads to exposure of sensitive financial documents and access to finance applications.
Has elevated privileges to investigate incidents; compromise may give attacker blue-team visibility and domain-level reach.
Any member account in this group is effectively a full-domain compromise if abused.
Members can control major application and web servers; often used as stepping stone to DB or DC.
Compromise of any member yields access to finance shares and business applications.
Compromise can isolate or expose the HR/Finance subnet, enabling or blocking access in bulk.
Firewall compromise here can expose payroll and HR databases/files directly to the core network.
Tier-0 for HR/Finance; full identity compromise of that subnet.
Ransomware or exfiltration here equates to HR data breach and high regulatory exposure.
High-value; compromise leads directly to payroll data breach and potential financial fraud.
Application-layer breach can be used to read/modify HR data and pivot into HR DB and files.
Critical; compromise leads to full payroll DB exposure and potential payment redirection.
Breach equals HR data compromise and serious compliance impact.
Full compromise equates to catastrophic payroll/bank data exposure.
Entry point into HR data; compromise plus stolen DIANA creds is high risk.
Another HR entry point; often similar risk profile to hr-ws-1 but owned by a different user.
Finance entry point; likely path for attacks targeting payroll and banking data.
Key HR identity; theft of DIANA's creds enables deep manipulation of HR systems and data.
Payroll-focused identity; compromise is a direct route to payroll and bank data manipulation.
Standard HR identity; still sensitive due to HR data access, but less powerful than DIANA.
Provides broad HR data access to members; bulk HR data is exposed if group is abused.
HR admin group with elevated privileges on HR app and HR DC; compromise is near-full HR environment control.
Controls access to payroll data; abuse leads to fraud potential and significant regulatory breach.
